questions.text: A 19-year-old young girl with a previous history of repeated pain over medial canthus and chronic use of nasal decongestants presented with abrupt onset of fever and chills and rigour, diplopia on lateral gaze, moderate proptosis and chemosis. On examination, the optic disc is congested. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cavernous Sinus Thrombosis Cavernous sinus thrombosis is sequela, resulting from the spread of sepsis travelling along its tributaries from the infected sinuses, teeth, ears, nose, and skin of the face. Very rarely cavernous sinus thrombosis may also occur after trauma (head injury). Communications of the cavernous sinus and sources of infection . Anteriorly, the superior and inferior ophthalmic veins drain into the sinus. These veins receive blood from the face, nose, paranasal sinuses and orbits. Therefore, infection to the cavernous sinus may spread from infected facial wounds, erysipelas, squeezing of style, furuncles, orbital cellulitis and sinusitis . Posteriorly, the superior and inferior petrosal sinuses leave it to join the lateral sinus. Labyrinthine veins opening into the inferior petrosal sinuses bring infections from the middle ear. Mastoid emissary veins may spread infection from the mastoid air cells. Superiorly, the cavernous sinus communicates with veins of the cerebrum and may be infected by meningitis and cerebral abscesses. Inferiorly , the sinus communicates with the pterygoid venous plexus. Medially , the two cavernous sinuses are connected with each other by transverse sinuses which account for the transfer of infection from one side to the other.

Highyeild:

Clinical features Cavernous sinus thrombosis starts initially as a unilateral condition, which soon becomes bilateral due to intercavernous communication. General features. Most patients are seriously ill having high-grade fever with chills and rigours, vomiting and headache. Ocular features include: Severe pain in the eye and forehead on the affected side. Conjunctiva is swollen and congested. Proptosis Ipsilateral ophthalmoplegia, causing diplopia, may occur due to palsy of the 3rd, 4th and 6th cranial nerves. Ipsilateral ptosis, dilated pupil, and absence of direct as well as consensual pupillary light reflex are signs of 3rd nerve palsy. Corneal anaesthesia, i.e., loss of corneal reflex , may occur due to the involvement of the ophthalmic division of the 5th cranial nerve. Oedema in the mastoid region is a pathognomonic sign. It is due to back pressure in the mastoid emissary vein.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Orbital cellulitis Option: C. Acute ethmoidal sinusitis Option: D. Orbital apex syndrome

Extraedge:

Investigations CT scan head and orbit may show involvement of cavernous sinuses and proptosis. Magnetic resonance venography (angiography) is the investigation of choice which shows an absence of flow void in thrombosed sinuses. A blood culture is recommended for sepsis. Complications - hyperpyrexia and signs of meningitis or pulmonary infarction may precede death.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man with a history of repeated pain over the medial canthus and chronic use of nasal decongestants presents to the outpatient department with high-grade fever and chills, headache, and bilateral proptosis. On eliciting further history, it is brought to light that the proptosis began in the right eye, and a few days later, the left eye was also affected. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cavernous sinus thrombosis The cavernous sinuses are irregularly shaped, trabeculated cavities located at the base of the skull. The cavernous sinuses are the most centrally located of the dural sinuses and lie on either side of the sella turcica. These sinuses are just lateral and superior to the sphenoid sinus and are immediately posterior to the optic chiasm, Periorbital edema may be the earliest physical finding. Chemosis results from occlusion of the ophthalmic veins. Lateral gaze palsy (isolated cranial nerve VI) is usually seen first since CN VI lies freely within the sinus in contrast to CN III and IV, which lie within the lateral walls of the sinus. Ptosis, mydriasis, and eye muscle weakness from cranial nerve III dysfunction Manifestations of increased retrobulbar pressure follow. Exophthalmos Ophthalmoplegia

Highyeild:

Communications of the cavernous sinus and sources of infection . Anteriorly, the superior and inferior ophthalmic veins drain into the sinus. These veins receive blood from the face, nose, paranasal sinuses and orbits. Therefore, infection to cavernous sinus may spread from infected facial wounds, erysipelas, squeezing of stye, furuncles, orbital cellulitis and sinusitis . Posteriorly, the superior and inferior petrosal sinuses leave it to join the lateral sinus. Labyrinthine veins opening into the inferior petrosal sinuses bring infections from the middle ear. Mastoid emissary veins may spread infection from the mastoid air cells. Superiorly, the cavernous sinus communicates with veins of the cerebrum and may be infected by meningitis and cerebral abscesses. Inferiorly , the sinus communicates with the pterygoid venous plexus. Medially , the two cavernous sinuses are connected with each other by transverse sinuses which account for the transfer of infection from one side to the other.

Panphthalmitis Panophthalmitis is the inflammation of the whole eyeball including tendons structure. It can be caused by infection, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Clostridium species, Whipple's disease, and fungi . Clinical features- Severe ocular pain and headache Complete LOV Profuse watering Purulent discharge Marked redness and swelling Associated constitutional symptoms

Magnetic resonance venography (angiography) is the investigation of choice which shows an absence of flow void in thrombosed sinuses. A blood culture is recommended for sepsis. questions.text: A 20-year-old man complains of difficulty in reading the newspaper with his right eye, 3 weeks after sustaining a gunshot injury to his left eye. The most likely diagnosis is?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Sympathetic ophthalmia Sympathetic ophthalmitis is serious bilateral granulomatous panuveitis which follows penetrating ocular trauma The injured eye is called the exciting eye, the fellow eye also develops uveitis is called sympathizing eye Clinical features- The exciting eye shows clinical features of persistent low-grade plastic uveitis, which include ciliary congestion, lacrimation and tenderness. KP may also be present Sympathizing eye usually involves 4-8 weeks of injury in the other eye. Sympathetic ophthalmitis manifests as acute plastic iridocyclitis.

Highyeild:

Prophylaxis- early excision of the injured eye Meticulous repair

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Macular edema Option: C. Optic nerve avulsion Option: D. Delayed vitreous haemorrhage

Extraedge:

Treatment when sympathetic ophthalmitis has already supervened Enucleation Corticosteroids Immunosuppressants Atropine

questions.text: Treatment of choice for 'advanced' panophthalmitis is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Evisceration Panophthalmitis is the inflammation of the whole eyeball including tendons structure. It can be caused by infection, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Clostridium species, Whipple's disease, and fungi . Clinical features- Severe ocular pain and headache Complete LOV Profuse watering Purulent discharge Marked redness and swelling Associated constitutional symptoms

Highyeild:

Signs - Lids edema and hyperemia The eyeball is proposed, and ocular movements restricted Conjunctiva shows chemosis and ciliary congestion The cornea is cloudy and edematous The anterior chamber is full of pus Vision is completely lost and perception of light is absent IOP is raised markedly Globe perforation may occur at the limbus

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Enucleation Option: C. Exenteration Option: D. conservative It is not done in the advanced stage of this disease.

Extraedge:

Complications- orbital cellulitis Cavernous sinus thrombosis Meningitis or encephalitis.

Solution:

CT Orbital cellulitis refers to an acute infection of soft tissues of orbit behind the orbital septum. Causative organisms-streptococcus pneumoniae, staphylococcus aureus, streptococcus pyogenes and H influenza Clinical features Swelling and severe pain which increases with eye movements Associated with general symptoms like fever, nausea, vomiting, prostration LOV and / or diplopia Swelling of lids, characterized by Swelling of lids, characterized by and redness Chemosis of conjunctiva Axial proptosis Restriction of ocular movements RAPD Fundus examination reveals papillitis and papilledema

questions.text: A 26-year-old man with a history of blunt trauma to the head 2 months earlier presented with rapidly progressive swelling, pain, and diminishing vision in the left eye. The physical examination of the left eye revealed chemosis and pulsating proptosis. A bruit could be heard with a stethoscope placed on the left temple. The most probable diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Carotid-Cavernous Fistula Results from an AV fistula between the carotid artery and cavernous sinus usually after head injury Can present at any age Presents bilaterally , but begins unilaterally It presents with pulsatile proptosis , associated with bruit and thrill MRI/ CT - the prominence of the superior ophthalmic vein and diffuse enlargement of extraocular muscles

Highyeild:

Other clinical features- Ophthalmoplegia - 3rd ,4th ,6th CN palsy Dilated tortuous episcleral veins lead to raise IOP DOV Swelling Pain Orbital and conjunctival congestion with chemosis

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B . Hematoma Option: C. Superior orbital fissure syndrome Option: D. Orbital apex syndrome

Extraedge:

Investigation of choice is - digital subtraction carotid angiography

questions.text: A child presented with unilateral proptosis which was compressible and increased on bending forwards. No thrill or bruit was present. MRI shows a retro-orbital mass with enhancement with echogenic shadows. What is the most probable condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Orbital varix Forward displacement of the globe relative to the orbital rims is known as proptosis Normally, 14 mm to 21 mm If > 21 mm or > 2 mm difference between two eyes indicates proptosis It can be measured by Hertel exophthalmometer and Luddle exophthalmometer Intermittent proptosis- proptosis that increases on bending forward or with Valsalva manoeuvre - orbital varices Proptosis exacerbated with upper respiratory tract infection - orbital lymphangioma Increased proptosis on straining or crying - capillary hemangioma or encephalocele Pulsatile proptosis - Carotid cavernous fistula Bony defects in the orbital roof, in patients with neurofibromatosis type I, meningocele and trauma

Highyeild:

Orbital varices- It is a congenital enlargement of the pre-existing venous channels resulting from a weakened orbital venous system Presents in early childhood to late middle age Most commonly presents unilaterally ( nasally) It is non-pulsatile and has a bag of worm consistency . The patient may develop acute orbital haemorrhage or thrombosis It is compressible Not associated with bruit/ thrill Precipitating factor - as the orbital veins are devoid of valves rapidly reversible proptosis may be precipitated by Valsalva manoeuvre and on bending forwards MRI/ CT reveals phleboliths

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Orbital Av Malformation. Option: C. Orbital encephalocele Option: D. Neurofibromatosis
